text: @Psych_Writer "iffy" sounds like an allegation that something was done wrong, which is not what I'm saying.
@Psych_Writer I didn't say that! I don't think the results reporting is complete enough, which makes it difficult to interpret.
Nice article by @Psych_Writer but the paper needed to report more stats (ideally CIs on mm^3/yr and on differences) https://t.co/R5eJoQAd49
@Psych_Writer So we can't be sure that e.g. female right caudate isn't just slightly less significant than male (R = −0.376, pcorr < 0.033).
@Psych_Writer Paper doesn't seem to report (or plot) the NS correlations (with exception of left thalamus in men, R = −0.345, pcorr < 0.069)
@Psych_Writer "only the men showed age-related reductions in caudate nucleus and putamen volume" but no mention of significant interaction?

RT @tjahain: Interesting article where a journal's editor-in-chief offers hints on how to have your manuscript sent for review:
https://t.c…
@sampendu @richarddmorey @rogierK @lakens Even just CC-BY requires that the original material's licence is mentioned along with attribution.
@sampendu @richarddmorey @rogierK @lakens The SA clause relates to contributions that "build upon the material" - they keep CC-BY-SA.
@sampendu @lakens If you want to enforce clearly showing/linking licence only for commercial use, then run into same problems of NC clause.
@sampendu @lakens You were talking (I thought) about stronger version of CC *BY* clause, so irrelevant whether Twitter considered NC or not.
@sampendu To be clear; I repeated mentioned collections of many articles; was not suggesting it would have been awkward for single article.
@sampendu Because main pages are typically brief (perhaps even strictly word-limited?). Anyway, we can agree: visible in sample or linked.
@sampendu @lakens Also, would we need to add licensing info when tweeting a figure from a CCBY paper?? Currently linking suffices as attrib.
@sampendu @lakens Well, other than repeating myself that it could be awkward to list for *many* articles, not sure what to add...
@sampendu @lakens Outside of paywall is a great idea, but I thought you wanted it on the main Amazon listing itself, which would be awkward.
@sampendu @lakens Inclined to agree; but it is potentially awkward for e.g. pack of teaching material with (parts of) *many* articles.
@sampendu I thought you were suggesting that the Amazon page itself would have to show attrib and licence (rather than just inside book) no?
@chrisdc77 @sampendu Well Sam started it (as I believe all good arguments go...) https://t.co/fGaMkr4qxt
Another interesting idea on CC BY +/- NC debate; but would this cause problems for collections of many articles? https://t.co/LiLWf6QOAq
@rogierK Aren't you also violating the attribution term there? Better hope the author can't afford a good lawyer ;-)
@sampendu Or what if a school wants to buy a pack of teaching material that includes your article among other stuff? NC/FU line is unclear.
@sampendu So what about a Spotify-like service? What if a reader knows it's free but *wants* to pay for a printed and posted book version?
An interesting thread arguing about CC-BY +/- NC. Do we need a new (@creativecommons?) licence in between these two? https://t.co/7Pc6heLpym
@sampendu @tom_hartley @richarddmorey @lakens @rogierK But in their blog post, they are actively arguing against the need for a new licence.
RT @jpeelle: So far we’ve had 0 applicants for our research assistant position! Is the job market that good? Please RT https://t.co/98x8q4X…
@sampendu @tom_hartley @richarddmorey @lakens @rogierK I don't follow you, WT can't do what? WT like CC-BY (not NC) https://t.co/Q34u7ASCUO
@tom_hartley @sampendu @richarddmorey @lakens @rogierK [2/2] actual "selling" without also prohibiting use by Wikipedia, universities, etc.
@tom_hartley @sampendu @richarddmorey @lakens Guys, you need to read some of the links that @rogierK and I sent... It's hard to stop [1/2]
RT @brandmaier: The authors really expected an age effect! https://t.co/1ktrqPVri4
@sampendu @richarddmorey @lakens @rogierK But I think you are underestimating the problems with NC, and overestimating problems without it.
@sampendu @richarddmorey @lakens @rogierK My understanding is that they only care about licence when paying an APC, so preprints can be NC.
@sampendu You might have missed this in the cofactor post that I linked, but seems NC=personal-use-only in Germany https://t.co/CAXMEw0vDv
@sampendu @richarddmorey @lakens @rogierK Organisations that carefully considered this (e.g. RCUK, Wellcome, FWF) request CC-BY without NC.
@lakens @VandekerckhoveJ Also, five dollars is very cheap compared to the per article purchase price of most closed access journals (~30).
@lakens @VandekerckhoveJ But if they'd found the free version, they obviously wouldn't pay; so this can only increase readership.
@sampendu @richarddmorey @lakens Adding to what @rogierK said/linked, NC leaves doubts about even academic use - https://t.co/XD8Am0jrSM

@AlxEtz @sampendu @annemscheel What cd be more Bayesian than p(thing you want to quantify belief in | things you've observed and assumed)?!
@sampendu @AlxEtz @annemscheel Yeah, but can consider p(Mi|D), normalised by summing over chosen set of M. Arguably more Bayesian than BFs.
@AlxEtz @annemscheel Realised that just after sending. Should have stuck to joke about ten... What I was thinking of was normalised p(Mi|D)
@AlxEtz @annemscheel Ten? How many hypotheses do you have? But seriously, why doesn't BFi suffice for i (of possibly more than 2) vs others?
